quantityRules.description: Axolotls are solitary and do best when housed alone. A 30-40 gallon breeder tank is minimum for one adult. Tank length and width matter more than height since they are bottom-dwelling.

humidity.notes: Fully aquatic species - humidity not applicable. Maintain clean, cold water instead.

lighting.photoperiod: Natural/indoor light sufficient - no special lighting needed

careTargets.gradient: Aquatic species - no thermal gradient needed. Maintain stable cold water temperature 60-68Â°F throughout tank.

lifespan: 10-15 years in captivity with proper care
originRegion: Lake Xochimilco, Mexico (Critically Endangered in wild)
setupTips: Tank MUST be fully cycled before adding axolotl - cycling takes 4-6 weeks minimum
Length and width more important than height - they're bottom-dwelling aquatic animals
Use low-flow filters only - high water flow causes stress (they evolved in still water)
Temperature is CRITICAL - never exceed 72Â°F or axolotl can die. Use aquarium chiller if room temperature is warm
Fine sand substrate only for axolotls 6+ inches. NO gravel, rocks, or marbles (causes impaction)
Bare-bottom tanks or slate tile are safest substrate options
NO eyelids - provide dark hiding spots to escape bright light
Aquarium lid essential - axolotls can jump out of tank
Test water weekly with liquid test kit.
Perform 20-30% water changes weekly with cold, conditioned water
notes: Fully aquatic - never leaves water (neotenic salamander that retains juvenile features for life)
Bottom-dwelling with poor eyesight - uses powerful sensory organs to detect movement
Critically Endangered in wild - only found in Lake Xochimilco, Mexico
Can regenerate lost limbs, gills, tail, and even parts of brain and heart
NO eyelids - evolved in darkness, need hiding spots to escape light
Sensitive to water quality - ammonia and nitrites must be 0 ppm at all times
Cold-water species - cannot tolerate warm temperatures (72Â°F+ can be fatal)
Solitary animals that don't require companionship - best kept alone
Juveniles under 6 inches should NEVER have substrate (impaction risk too high)
Adults 6+ inches can have extremely fine sand only - still risky
Produces significant waste - requires strong filtration and weekly water changes

warnings.message: TEMPERATURE EXTREME DANGER - Never allow water to exceed 72Â°F. Temperatures above 74Â°F can be rapidly fatal. Use aquarium chiller or room AC if ambient temps are warm. Axolotls cannot thermoregulate.

CYCLING MANDATORY - Tank MUST be fully cycled before adding axolotl. Uncycled tanks cause ammonia poisoning which is often fatal. Cycling takes 4-6 weeks minimum. Test water parameters before purchase.
IMPACTION DANGER - NO gravel, rocks, marbles, or glass stones. Axolotls accidentally swallow these causing fatal blockages. Use bare-bottom, slate tile, or extremely fine sand (6+ inches only).
WATER QUALITY CRITICAL - Ammonia and nitrites MUST be 0 ppm at all times. Even trace amounts cause chemical burns to gills and skin. Test water weekly. Perform 20-30% water changes weekly minimum.
ALOE VERA TOXICITY - Never use water conditioners containing aloe vera or plant extracts. These are toxic to axolotls. Use Seachem Prime or Fritz Complete only.
LOW FLOW REQUIRED - High water flow causes severe stress. Use low-flow filters with adjustable flow rates. Aim filter output toward surface, not directly at axolotl.
TANK MATE RISKS - Fish nip gills/limbs, shrimp/crayfish attack with claws, small snails cause impaction. Best kept alone. Only bladder/pond snails safe for 4+ inch axolotls.
FEEDER FISH DANGER - Live feeder fish carry parasites, bacteria, and fungal infections. If using, quarantine fish 2+ weeks and treat. Frozen silversides or worms much safer.
NO DISTILLED/RO WATER - Distilled and reverse osmosis water lack minerals essential for axolotl health. Use conditioned tap water, spring water, or well water only.
LIGHTING SENSITIVITY - Axolotls have no eyelids and evolved in darkness. Bright lights cause stress. Natural room light is sufficient. Provide dark hides for retreat.

feedingRequirements: Obligate carnivores - require whole prey items (worms, small fish, insects)
Food must be small enough to fit in mouth without choking
Axolotls inhale prey using suction feeding - don't chew
NEVER feed mealworms - tough exoskeleton causes impaction
feedingSchedule: Adults (8+ inches): Feed once every 2-3 days, as much as they'll eat in 10-15 minutes
Juveniles (under 8 inches): Feed daily, as much as they'll eat in 10-15 minutes
Remove uneaten food after 30 minutes to prevent water quality degradation
Variety is important - rotate between different staple foods
feedingVariety: STAPLES: Earthworms/nightcrawlers (4+ inches), blackworms (under 4 inches), frozen silversides, frozen brine shrimp cubes, Repashy Grub Pie
OCCASIONAL (1-2Ã— monthly): Waxworms, hornworms (horn removed), crickets, bloodworms
AVOID: Mealworms (tough exoskeleton), goldfish (high in thiaminase), any food larger than space between eyes
supplementSchedule: No supplementation required - whole prey items provide complete nutrition
Earthworms and frozen fish contain all necessary vitamins and minerals
Do NOT use calcium powder or vitamin supplements designed for reptiles
waterNotes: Fully aquatic - entire tank is their water feature
20-30% water changes weekly with cold, conditioned water
Never use conditioners with aloe vera or plant extracts
handlingNotes: Minimize handling - causes extreme stress and damages protective slime coat
Use fine mesh net for transfers (never hands)
If handling unavoidable: wet hands thoroughly, support entire body, minimize time out of water
Never lift by tail, gills, or limbs
Return to water immediately if axolotl struggles or gasps
substrateOptions: SAFEST: Bare-bottom tank (easiest to clean, no impaction risk)
SAFE: Slate tile (natural look, no impaction risk, easy to clean)
RISKY: Extremely fine sand (pool filter sand or play sand) - ONLY for axolotls 6+ inches
NEVER USE: Gravel, rocks, marbles, glass stones, coarse sand, artificially colored sand
commonIssues: Floating: Gulped too much air during feeding. Usually self-resolves in 24 hours. If persistent, check water quality.
Curled gills: Poor water quality (ammonia/nitrites present) or temperature too warm. Test water immediately.
Loss of appetite: Stress from acclimation (normal 2-3 days), water too warm, poor water quality, or illness.
Frantic swimming: Water quality issue (ammonia/nitrites spike), temperature spike, or extreme stress. Test water and lower temperature.
Fungus on gills/body: Use Indian almond leaves for mild cases, black tea bath for moderate, methylene blue for severe. Always address underlying water quality issue.
tankMateCompatibility: BEST ALONE: Axolotls are solitary and thrive when housed individually
Multiple axolotls: Possible in 40+ gallon tanks with 2-3 adults maximum. Monitor for aggression and nipping.
Bladder/pond snails: Safe for axolotls 4+ inches. Help clean tank.
NEVER: Fish (nip gills/limbs), shrimp/crayfish (attack with claws), mystery/apple snails under 2 inches (impaction risk)
cyclingRequirements: Tank MUST be cycled before axolotl introduction - non-negotiable
Cycling establishes beneficial bacteria to process ammonia â†’ nitrites â†’ nitrates
Process takes 4-6 weeks minimum - cannot be rushed
Use fishless cycling method: add ammonia source, test daily, wait for bacteria colony
Cycle is complete when: Ammonia and nitrites stay at 0 ppm after adding ammonia
Never add axolotl to uncycled tank - causes fatal ammonia poisoning

regions: Lake Xochimilco, Mexico (only remaining natural habitat)
biomes: Shallow lake with muddy bottom, heavy vegetation, cool water
nativeHabitat.conservationStatus: Critically Endangered (IUCN Red List) - one step above extinct in wild
